Volunteering

10/08/2012

There are many volunteering opportunities available at York

Image by

By James Bithell

There are a host of volunteering opportunities at York, from working with kids to undertaking conservation projects. As well as being a worthwhile activity and a benefit to the local community, employers rank volunteering pursuits highly when looking at CVs. In the same way that you can join any number of societies, you don't have to just limit yourself to one volunteering exploit each week. The flagship project is 'Kids Camp', which takes place in the Easter and Summer holidays. Volunteers spend a week with children who are referred by social services at an indoor scout camp near York. The Camp involves a number of activity days and is great for the kids - giving them an opportunity to do activities they wouldn't usually do - and great for volunteers - you develop skills in leadership and team building. One of York's great selling points is its diverse number of societies and volunteering projects, and as well as 'Kids Camp' there are many other different projects that you can get involved with: either simply as a volunteer, or as part of the committee.

Projects - click for more information

Kids Club Kids Camp Babylon EcoVolunteers eVent KEEN All About Animals Theatre in Schools MEG Minds in Motion Tea & Coffee Club Viva Voce Sexpression Inkwell
Kids Club Every Saturday a group of volunteers, led by a project co-ordinator, go off in a minibus and take a group of children from the York area on a variety of daytrips. These children are aged between 8 and 12 and they are referred to us by social services as being "desperately in need of a break". Their home circumstances vary from being young carers to victims of domestic violence to children recently put into care. Trips recently have included a huge two minibus trip to the seaside, a trip to the Circus, trips swimming, and the ever popular Creepy Crawlies indoor play centre. Contact: kidsclub@yusu.org

Kids Camp Kids Camp is similar to Kids Club but involves taking children on a week-long activity holiday, instead of just day trips, based at an indoor scout camp in Stockton on Forest, York. The children's circumstances range from being victims of domestic violence, young carers and children in care. Kids Camp gives them an opportunity to be kids. It also gives students an opportunity to develop skills in leadership, team building and initiative. Kids Camp includes various activity days, including day trips, sports and arts activities. Contact: kidscamp@yusu.org

Babylon Babylon is a volunteering project which sees students teaching French, German, and Spanish in primary schools across York as an after-school club. Luckily, you don't have to be fluent to teach--remember, most of the kids are aged between 3 and 11. Contact: babylon@yusu.org

EcoVolunteers EcoVolunteers undertake all manner of conservation projects, both little and large, to conserve and promote all aspects of British wildlife. Many of the sites that volunteers work on are designated Nature Reserves and Sites of Special Scientific Interest, and feature a number of diverse habitats including seasonally flooding hay-meadows, extensive woodland valleys, botanically rich peat-bogs, vast country estates and coastal mud-flats. Contact: conservation@yusu.org

eVent eVent is an event volunteering projects where students can help out at various events throughout the University year. For example, sport events like Roses and Varsity and music events like Woodstock. Contact: eventvolunteers@yusu.org


KEEN KEEN (Kids enjoy exercise now) is a weekly run, hour-long sport session for children with disabilities. Every Sunday at 1pm in the sports centre volunteers and the children participate in activities such as bowling, trampolining, bench ball and unbeatable playground classics such as duck duck goose. Not only do the children love it, but it's great for the volunteers too.
"KEEN not only looks great on your CV and for all the boring reasons, but it also means you get to make a child laugh every Sunday, escape from essays playing parachute games and most importantly try and beat the rest of the volunteers" - Sophie Large
Contact: keen@yusu.org

Theatre in Schools Theatre in schools is ideal for anyone interested in drama as the project works with children in nearby schools teaching them about drama and also making sure they have a good time. Contact: theatreinschools@yusu.org

MEG The Music Education Group, aka MEG is a friendly student run organisation working with the local community to achieve 'Music for All'. MEG's biggest contribution are workshops with schools, including ukuleles, kazoo, recorder series, introduction to instruments, gospel singing and many more; they also provide performances for those with dementia at the harmony cafe, musical activities in the local children's ward, as well as having an annual musical. All students are welcome. They will be situated by the volunteering stands at Freshers' Fair. The website is http://megyork.wix.com/meg#! which will hopefully be updated by the beginning of next term.
"Personally my favourite part of MEG is the reactions you receive from the children after a successful workshop or event." - Layla
"The best part is using music to give back to the community." - Tamsin
Contact: meg@yusu.org

Minds in Motion Minds in Motion (MIM) is a community group set up to help support people with dementia and their carers. Volunteers work in different teams to put on activities for people with dementia at local community units for the elderly. At present there are six activities: arts & crafts, singing, dance & movement, interactive music, reminiscence, and gardening & restoration.
"I really enjoy volunteering with Minds in Motion, it provides a rewarding opportunity to get involved with the local community and brighten up someone's day" - Naomi Dickinson
Contact: mindsinmotion@yusu.org

Tea and Coffee Club Tea and Coffee Club enriches the lives of older residents of York with weekly on-campus coffee mornings and termly trips out. The project promotes a relationship with the community around York in an atmosphere of mutual warmth, friendship and interest. This nurtures a strong social network that spans two or three generations. They create a space in which people can relax, socialise, play games (bingo), share stories and be around people who are different from their everyday faces. Go along, and have some cake, to see what is on offer.
"Tea and Coffee Club offers a friendly, informal atmosphere for relaxing, chatting and getting to know our older members. Anybody who can spare the time for an occasional cup of tea on the sofa should come and say hello!" - Hannah Pitts
Contact: teaandcoffee@yusu.org

Viva Voce Viva Voce is an online audio magazine for blind and visually impaired young adults (18-25 year olds). Each issue features comment, lifestyle, review, creative writing, sports and feature articles. All of these articles are written, edited and recorded aloud by students of the University of York, but they are available for everybody to listen to. Viva Voce aims to bring up to date issues and entertainment to young people who cannot access magazine articles in their traditional format. Contact: vivavoce@yusu.org

Sexpression Sexpression is one branch of a nationwide, peer led sexual education programme. It provides students with training and the opportunity to teach relationship and sexual education to children aged 12-16. Contact: sexpression@yusu.org

Inkwell Inkwell volunteers work with children aged 13-15 who love reading to pass on their enthusiasm to others through reading groups, presentations and workshops. Contact: inkwell@yusu.org

All About Animals All About Animals is a student run volunteering group especially for animal causes. It works closely with the RSPCA providing regular volunteering opportunities in animal care including dog walking, cat socialising, rabbit grooming and much more. Contact: allaboutanimals@yusu.org

For more information visit: www.yusu.org/volunteering
